item.title: Fashion Image Recognition – CNN with 98% Accuracy
item.description:
This project implements a modern Convolutional Neural Network trained on the Fashion-MNIST dataset.

Highlights

  • Trained on 10,000+ images of clothing (bags, sneakers, shirts, t-shirts, etc.)
  • Achieved around 98% accuracy on the test set
  • Includes:
    • Model definition (model_class.py)
    • Data utilities (data.py)
    • A small Streamlit app (streamlit_app.py) for interactive inference

It’s a concrete example of:

  • Building and training a non-trivial model
  • Structuring code into reusable components
  • Wrapping models in a simple app for demos or stakeholders

item.title: Tkinter Stock Market Widget
item.description:
A small desktop widget built using Tkinter to track:

  • Market indices
  • Selected individual stocks

The goal was to have a lightweight, always-on-top widget that let me keep an eye on markets without a full browser or terminal session.

It is simple, but it shows:

  • Comfort with Tkinter and UI basics
  • Ability to turn an idea into a working tool, even if minimal
  • Willingness to iterate on design and usability

item.title: Personal Finance Dashboard – Net Worth & Asset Allocation
item.description:
This project is a blueprint for a personal finance dashboard to track:

  • Bank balances and interest rates
  • Indian equity holdings + prices
  • Mutual fund units + NAVs
  • PPF holdings + interest
  • Gold holdings and prices
  • US stocks
  • Credit card balances

The Outline.txt in the repo documents the thought process:

What do we need to keep track of?
What should the dashboard show daily?
How can we alert on big moves?

item.title: Portfolio Viewer – CLI tool with SQLite + Yahoo Finance
item.description:
A command-line portfolio tracker that stores holdings in a local SQLite database and fetches prices automatically from Yahoo Finance.

Originally built as my CS50 final project, but designed to be genuinely useful.

Features

  • Add stocks with quantity – price is auto-fetched from Yahoo Finance
  • View portfolio in a nicely formatted table using tabulate
  • See live values in your terminal without opening a browser or Excel

Tech

  • Python
  • SQLite (via sqlite3)
  • yfinance for market data
  • Clean, argument-based CLI (portfolio_tool.py)

This project shows my comfort with Python, databases, APIs, and building real tools, not just notebooks.

item.title: Text-to-SQL Finetuned LLMs
item.description:
In this project, I fine-tuned small language models to convert English questions → SQL queries.

Goal

Make it easy for non-technical users to query structured data by just typing:

“Show me all users who signed up last week with more than 3 orders”

and get back:

SELECT *
FROM users
WHERE signup_date >= DATE('now', '-7 days')
  AND order_count > 3;

What’s inside
	•	Finetune_SQL.ipynb – notebook for preparing training data, formatting prompts, and running the fine-tuning loop
	•	README with the high-level idea

item.title: sparse_nano_transformer – Iterating on the base transformer
item.description:
This repo extends the original nano_transformers work into a more experimental playground.

I use it to:

  • Try out sparser or more efficient variants of the transformer
  • Prototype changes to attention, batching, or training setups
  • Keep my understanding fresh by tweaking and breaking things

It reflects how I learn: start with a clean baseline, then iterate, refactor, and experiment.

item.title: nano_transformers – Building a GPT-style model from scratch
item.description:
I built a small decoder-only transformer (Shakespeare GPT) from scratch in PyTorch, inspired by Andrej Karpathy’s nanoGPT series.

Why I built this

There’s only one real way to understand transformers — implement them yourself:

  • Tokenization
  • Embeddings
  • Multi-head self-attention
  • Residual connections
  • Training loop & sampling

What’s inside the repo

  • bigram.ipynb – main notebook implementing and training the model
  • train.py – script to train on a dataset end-to-end
  • inferencing_trained_model.ipynb – sampling from the trained model and generating Shakespeare-like text

The model was trained on a Tesla T4 GPU, and I was able to drive the training loss down to around 0.97.
